content.body: Domenic: I think special cased is the way to go, though it makes me wonder how the other positional methods should end up working there, `beforeUnsafeHTML` and such
content.formatted_body: Domenic: I think special cased is the way to go, though it makes me wonder how the other positional methods should end up working there, beforeUnsafeHTML and such

content.body: Domenic: and yeah, it should be available on `ShadowRoot` too
content.formatted_body: Domenic: and yeah, it should be available on ShadowRoot too

content.body: I'm looking at the URL object protocol setter: https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-url-protocol

the latter has

> If state override is given, then:
> If url’s scheme is a special scheme and buffer is not a special scheme, then return.
content.formatted_body:
the latter has

If state override is given, then:
If url’s scheme is a special scheme and buffer is not a special scheme, then return.

content.body: does that mean that `x = new URL('http:bar'); x.protocol = 'notspecial'; x.protocol` should give me `http`?
content.formatted_body: does that mean that x = new URL('http:bar'); x.protocol = 'notspecial'; x.protocol should give me http?

content.body: * does that mean that `x = new URL('http:bar'); x.protocol = 'notspecial'; x.protocol` should give me `http:`?
content.formatted_body: * does that mean that x = new URL('http:bar'); x.protocol = 'notspecial'; x.protocol should give me http:?

m.new_content.body: does that mean that `x = new URL('http:bar'); x.protocol = 'notspecial'; x.protocol` should give me `http:`?
m.new_content.formatted_body: does that mean that x = new URL('http:bar'); x.protocol = 'notspecial'; x.protocol should give me http:?

content.body: it does in Node though, possibly because they were following the spec
